New Food Chief, Coulson, Plans
Good Levering, Dorm Service
Mr. Thomas C.- Coulson, new director of food service for the
Johns Hopkins University, plans
to "apply the principles of good
food service and use the ideas and
items of better restaurants" in the
dormitory and Levering Hall cafeterias. He does not, however, foresee any policy changes.
Declining comment on his exact budget figure,'Mr. Coulson
stated that "under a limited budget and a non-profit basis, we will
give the boys as much as we can."
He could not, however, indicate
any areas of improvement yet,
but said he is "pleased by the

type of people working in the
dorm and cafeteria."
Mr. Coulson finds the University "well set-up" in the food department and said that it is "a
pleasure to work here—there is
less competition than in commercial work."
Mr. Coulson was with the A. L.
Mathias Co.: industrial caterers
in Baltimore, for three years and
was also the manager of two restaurants in Toronto, Canada. A
graduate of the University of Toronto's Institute of Hotels and
Groseclose Restaurants, he is 38 years old,
married, and has two children.

Schneider, Dr. Emeritus,
Teaches German At JHU
Dr. Heinrich Schneider, professor emeritus of German at Harvard, will be guest professor in
German at Johns Hopkins University for the current academic
Year, 'according to a recent announcement from Hopkins' President Lowell J. Reed.•
Schneider will conduct a course
on "German Literature in the Age
of the Enlightenment" and seminars on Lessing, the 18th Century German critic and dramatist,
and Leibnitz, the 17th Century
Philosopher and mathematician.
Professor Schneider was born in
Germany and educated at the Uni-

versities of Tuebingen and Leipzig.
He received his doctorate in 1911
at.the University of Giessen, where
he later served as associate librarian and instructor in history.
In 1933, Schneider went into
political exile in Sofia, where he
was, for three years, professor of
German and head of the modern
language department at American
College.
After coming to the United
States in 1936, Schneider taught
German at Wheaton College and
Cornell University. In 1948, he
was appointed professor of German at Harvard.

Casing The Coaches
After a two-year hitch in the
armed forces, Gerald Williamson,
former Hopkins soccer star, has
returned to the Homewood Campus.
However, Williamson is now
serving as freshman soccer coach
instead of booting shots through
the opposition's goal as he did in
former years.
Williamson performed for the
Jays' varsity soccer team in 19511952. In the latter season, he was
chosen the Blue Jays' co-captain.
Most Valuable Booter
Born and raised in Wilbraham,
Massachusetts, Williamson received his schooling at Wilbraham Academy. During his high
school days, he participated in
soccer and tennis. In his senior
year, he was named the most valuable booter in the conference.
This, 24 year old, unmarried
mentor speaks very modestly of
his playing days and says that he
enjoys coaching the Jay freshmen.
Simon New Coach
Another one of the new Hopkins coaches, Mr. Lincoln Simon,
has the unique position of being
both a student and coach.
Mr. Simon, a 38 year old sophomore, decided to attend college
after his second hitch in the army
during the Korean War. Being
a great lover of sports but unable

to participate against younger
men, he has taken over the position of frosh and varsity crosscountry coach. In the Spring he
will assist Mr. Bridgers with the
track squad.
Hamburg, New York is considered by Simon as his hometown
and he named Hamburg High
School as his alma mater. While
attending high school, he participated in basketball, football, and
track. As a trackman, Simon performed in the high jump, pole
vault and discus events.
Serves In Two Wars
During World War II and the
Korean conflict, Simon served his
country as a member of the U. S.
Army and emerged as an officer.
It was during the Korean conflict
that he decided upon a college
education, a lifelong goal.
"I am very happy with my
coaching job and consider myself
fortunate to be able to coach here
at Hopkins," declared Mr. Simon.
"I have no ambition to become a
professional coach, however, I do
love sports."
Simon is married and the father
of a baby girl, who was born last
January shortly before mid-year
exams.

Johns Hopkins University, plans

any areas of improvement yet,
but said he is "pleased by the

type of people working in the
dorm and cafeteria."

pleasure to work here—there is
less competition than in commercial work."

Mathias Co.: industrial caterers
in Baltimore, for three years and
was also the manager of two restaurants in Toronto, Canada. A
graduate of the University of Toronto's Institute of Hotels and
Groseclose Restaurants, he is 38 years old,
married, and has two children.

Schneider, Dr. Emeritus,
Teaches German At JHU
Dr. Heinrich Schneider, professor emeritus of German at Harvard, will be guest professor in
German at Johns Hopkins University for the current academic
Year, 'according to a recent announcement from Hopkins' President Lowell J. Reed.•
Schneider will conduct a course
on "German Literature in the Age
of the Enlightenment" and seminars on Lessing, the 18th Century German critic and dramatist,
and Leibnitz, the 17th Century
Philosopher and mathematician.
Professor Schneider was born in
Germany and educated at the Uni-

versities of Tuebingen and Leipzig.
He received his doctorate in 1911
at.the University of Giessen, where
he later served as associate librarian and instructor in history.
In 1933, Schneider went into
political exile in Sofia, where he
was, for three years, professor of
German and head of the modern
language department at American
College.
After coming to the United
States in 1936, Schneider taught
German at Wheaton College and
Cornell University. In 1948, he
was appointed professor of German at Harvard.

Casing The Coaches
After a two-year hitch in the
armed forces, Gerald Williamson,
former Hopkins soccer star, has
returned to the Homewood Campus.
However, Williamson is now
serving as freshman soccer coach
instead of booting shots through
the opposition's goal as he did in
former years.
Williamson performed for the
Jays' varsity soccer team in 19511952. In the latter season, he was
chosen the Blue Jays' co-captain.
Most Valuable Booter
Born and raised in Wilbraham,
Massachusetts, Williamson received his schooling at Wilbraham Academy. During his high
school days, he participated in
soccer and tennis. In his senior
year, he was named the most valuable booter in the conference.
This, 24 year old, unmarried
mentor speaks very modestly of
his playing days and says that he
enjoys coaching the Jay freshmen.
Simon New Coach
Another one of the new Hopkins coaches, Mr. Lincoln Simon,
has the unique position of being
both a student and coach.
Mr. Simon, a 38 year old sophomore, decided to attend college
after his second hitch in the army
during the Korean War. Being
a great lover of sports but unable

to participate against younger
men, he has taken over the position of frosh and varsity crosscountry coach. In the Spring he
will assist Mr. Bridgers with the
track squad.
Hamburg, New York is considered by Simon as his hometown
and he named Hamburg High
School as his alma mater. While
attending high school, he participated in basketball, football, and
track. As a trackman, Simon performed in the high jump, pole
vault and discus events.
Serves In Two Wars
During World War II and the
Korean conflict, Simon served his
country as a member of the U. S.
Army and emerged as an officer.
It was during the Korean conflict
that he decided upon a college
education, a lifelong goal.
"I am very happy with my
coaching job and consider myself
fortunate to be able to coach here
at Hopkins," declared Mr. Simon.
"I have no ambition to become a
professional coach, however, I do
love sports."
Simon is married and the father
of a baby girl, who was born last
January shortly before mid-year
exams.
